coredata.dc:title: Transient photocurrent and photovoltage mapping for characterisation of defects in organic photovoltaics
coredata.prism:publicationName: Solar Energy Materials and Solar Cells
coredata.prism:copyright: Crown Copyright © 2016 Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:creator: Wood, Sebastian
O'Connor, Daniel
Jones, Christopher W.
Claverley, James D.
Blakesley, James C.
Giusca, Claudiu
Castro, Fernando A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Advances in organic photovoltaics have created the opportunity for low-cost, high-throughput manufacture of solar cells using roll-to-roll printing technology; however, the performance, reliability, and production yield of these devices can be critically limited by the incorporation of defects during fabrication. The detection and elimination of all printing defects is unrealistic, so techniques are required to identify those types of defects which are most critical to solar cell functionality. Here, we combine mapping of both surface topography and photovoltaic properties in order to understand the impact of various types of defect on the functional performance. To enable this comparison, transient photocurrent and photovoltage mapping is demonstrated as a technique for measuring local variation in charge carrier dynamics. We find that dust particle contamination corresponds with localised reductions in charge extraction rate. This novel measurement technique provides a way to distinguish between different types of defect by considering both the magnitude and dynamics of the local transient responses.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Diagram of the multilayer sample structure with a silica microsphere included to represent dust contamination (not to scale). Surface height maps of a 2.2mm by 1.7mm region of the sample measured after deposition of: (b) MoOx/Ag, (c) active layer, (d) ZnO, and (e) ITO. Note that the height scale has been truncated and missing data points are displayed in white. Labels ‘A–F’ in (c) identify specific features of interest.

Photocurrent maps of the OPV sample measured under light bias equivalent to 0.7 Suns: (a) complete sample including two 1cm2 cells with black rectangle corresponding with the area of interest in Fig. 1(b)–(e), and (b) detail of area of interest. Labels ‘A–F’ identify the positions of the features identified in Fig. 1(c).

Examples of (a) photovoltage, and (b) photocurrent transients measured at a single point showing the double exponential fitting lines and illustrating the parameters ΔV, aΔV, TV α, ΔI, aΔI, TI α, and ΔQ.

Transient photovoltage maps of (a) ΔV (peak photovoltage) for the whole device, (b) ΔV for the area of interest identified in Fig. 2, and (c) TV 0.1 (photovoltage decay time at α=0.1) for the same area.

Transient photocurrent maps of the area of interest identified in Fig. 2, showing (a) ΔQ (charge extracted), and (b) TI 0.1 (photocurrent decay time at α=0.1). (c) Scatter plot comparing values of TI 0.1 and ΔQ measured for each data point, showing distinct classes of light scattering defects and charge extraction defects. The mean values of these parameters are marked by a black ‘×’. Inset shows spatial distribution plot of the two defect populations identified using this technique.
Impact of defects ‘A–F’ on local steady state photocurrent generation and proposed identifications of defects.

head.ce:title: Transient photocurrent and photovoltage mapping for characterisation of defects in organic photovoltaics

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: National Physical Laboratory, Hampton Road, Teddington TW11 0LW, United Kingdom

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Advances in organic photovoltaics have created the opportunity for low-cost, high-throughput manufacture of solar cells using roll-to-roll printing technology; however, the performance, reliability, and production yield of these devices can be critically limited by the incorporation of defects during fabrication. The detection and elimination of all printing defects is unrealistic, so techniques are required to identify those types of defects which are most critical to solar cell functionality. Here, we combine mapping of both surface topography and photovoltaic properties in order to understand the impact of various types of defect on the functional performance. To enable this comparison, transient photocurrent and photovoltage mapping is demonstrated as a technique for measuring local variation in charge carrier dynamics. We find that dust particle contamination corresponds with localised reductions in charge extraction rate. This novel measurement technique provides a way to distinguish between different types of defect by considering both the magnitude and dynamics of the local transient responses.

ce:list-item.ce:para: Defect management in printed photovoltaics is critical for functional performance.
Silica microspheres provide a reference sample for dust defects.
Combined optical and functional mapping are used to identify defects.
Transient photoresponse mapping is demonstrated for defect categorisation.

ce:section.ce:para: It was recognised more than a decade ago that the economic viability of organic photovoltaic (OPV) technology is dependent upon the realisation of devices with a high power conversion efficiency (PCE), long operational lifetime, and low production cost [1]. Recent progress has led to PCEs above 11% for single junction organic solar cells, and there remains scope for further improvement [2,3]. These encouraging results have led to increased investment of resources into improving the operational lifetime and scaling up production of solar cells into a roll-to-roll printing process [4,5]. However, to produce high efficiency, stable OPVs on a large scale, it is important to mitigate the formation of defects, which can critically limit the device performance. OPV structures typically comprise multiple layers deposited in separate processes, and as a result, there are many different types of defect or inhomogeneity that may form. Some of these defects (e.g. shunt connections across the active layers) can be critical to the functionality of the device, whereas others are usually less serious (e.g. small variations in thickness of a metal electrode). It is, therefore, important to identify and quantify the critical defects for two reasons: to improve the manufacturing yield quickly by focusing on resolving the most critical problems, and to facilitate the implementation of in-line defect detection measurements based on machine learning and cataloguing defect types [6]. In practice, this requires an understanding of the impact of specific types of defects on the functional performance of the solar cell. In this study, we develop a transient photocurrent and photovoltage mapping technique as a probe for local variation in the dynamics of photogenerated charge carriers. By combining this novel measurement with surface topography data and steady state photocurrent mapping, we are able to identify different types of defects and correlate them with their impact on photovoltaic performance. As an example, we consider the effects of particulate contamination, which is a typical problem for printing processes, by incorporating silica microspheres of known dimension into solution-deposited solar cells as reference ‘dust’ defects. In this case, we observe spatial variations in the transient photocurrent decay lifetime indicating a locally reduced charge extraction rate.

Patterned indium tin oxide (ITO) substrates were first cleaned by ultrasonication in a series of acetone, Hellmanex detergent, deionised water, and isopropanol. Photovoltaic devices were then prepared in the inverted architecture: glass/ITO/ZnO/polymer:fullerene/MoOx/Ag. The ZnO layer was deposited by spin coating from a 160g/l solution of zinc acetate (obtained from Sigma Aldrich) in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and immediately baked at 300°C before rinsing with acetone and deionised water. Substrates were then dried at 140°C for 10min before transferring to a nitrogen-filled glovebox and baking for a further 10min. The active layer comprised OPV100 (an electron-donating polymer) and the electron-accepting fullerene derivative (PC61BM) both provided by Merck and dissolved in chlorobenzene with a ratio of 1:2 by weight, giving a 30mg/ml solution. The solution was stirred for 2h at 70°C to ensure complete dissolution, and deposited on to the ZnO layer by blade coating to give an active layer thickness of 300±20nm. Samples were dried at 70°C prior to deposition of the electrode by thermal evaporation of a 5nm layer of MoOx followed by 150nm of Ag, at <10-6 mbar vacuum. The deposited electrodes defined device active areas of 1cm2.

In order to create the simulated ‘dust’ defects, silica microspheres were obtained from Whitehouse Scientific with a nominal diameter of 9µm and dispersed in deionised water by ultrasonication with a concentration of roughly 106 microspheres/ml. For the samples incorporating the microspheres, the process described above was interrupted after the ZnO deposition and a droplet of the microsphere suspension was spin coated on to the centre of the sample at 4000rpm for 10s before drying at 80°C for 10min and then progressing to the active layer deposition.

A Talysurf CCI HD Coherent Scanning Interferometer (CSI) manufactured by Taylor Hobson was used for areal surface topography measurements. A CSI extracts surface topography by first projecting broadband light onto the sample through an interferometric objective, in this case, of the Mirau type, and then mechanically scanning the sample through the interference contrast envelope that peaks at zero optical path difference. A series of areal images is recorded at regular displacements during the mechanical scan. An algorithm then processes the acquired interference fringe contrast and phase information to determine a surface height for each pixel in the image stack.

The CSI was fitted with a 10× magnification objective lens (0.3 numerical aperture, working field of view of 1.66mm by 1.66mm and sampling distance of approximately 0.8µm) and used in stitching mode. The region size of the measured topography was 17.1mm by 17.1mm (slightly larger than the 16mm by 16mm sample), which was composed of 121 partially overlapped topographies in a measurement grid of 11 by 11. This raster and stitch measurement routine took approximately 4h to complete. The vast majority (>90%) of this time was associated with the automatic lateral repositioning and focusing of the sample, and not the individual CSI measurements. The raster and stitch measurement was repeated after each of the various layer deposition steps during the fabrication of the OPV device and required the removal of the sample to a separate laboratory on site. This necessitated the development of a procedure to reposition the sample under the CSI instrument with good repeatability in order to enable registration of data from multiple layers with a high confidence. While every effort was made to protect the sample, the repeated and extended exposure to ambient conditions has contributed to the high density of defects observed in this study, in addition to the artificial defects.

Interferometric surface topography measurements can be affected by phase change errors on reflection due to inhomogeneities in material composition, which could result in errors of up to a few tens of nanometres. In this case, however, the subsequent layer depositions of uniform material compositions exhibited dimensional features that correlated with those in the previous layer, which is evidence that these features are in fact real dimensional defects propagating through the fabrication process and not simply artefacts of the optical measurement.

Laser beam induced current mapping was performed using a ReRa SpeQuest system customised with a Zaber x-y sample translation stage and modified optics to focus the 532nm diode laser onto the sample. The spatial resolution was limited by the laser spot size (estimated to be 70–90µm in diameter). A Thorlabs LCC3111 noise eater, positioned before the Thorlabs MC2000 mechanical chopper (270Hz), was used to stabilise the laser output power (5 μW average incident on sample), and the photocurrent signal was amplified with a large dynamic range Melles Griot pre-amplifier and measured using a Stanford Research SR830 digital lock-in amplifier. An OSLON 80 9+ PowerStar LED array (peak emission at 617nm) was used as a bias light, to control the open-circuit voltage of the device in order to approximate operational conditions during measurements.

Photovoltage & photocurrent transients were measured by connecting the sample device to a Tektronix DPO4104B oscilloscope (1MΩ input impedance for transient photovoltage and 50Ω for transient photocurrent) and exposing the sample to an excitation pulse from a Sirah PrecisionScan dye laser delivering pulses of duration <10ns, with wavelength 635nm, a frequency of 10Hz, and a pulse energy of 4mJ. Spatial resolution was provided by focusing the excitation laser pulse to a spot approximately 50µm in diameter, and translating the sample on a 2-axis stage to raster over the area of interest. Electrical noise generated by the 2-axis stage presents a significant problem, which is discussed further below.

The sample was contained within a nitrogen-filled sample chamber to prevent degradation, and no change in the transient response was observed on the time scales considered in this work. Transient responses were averaged over 64 measurements for each sample position.

After each layer deposition step of the device fabrication process (see Fig. 1(a)), the topography of the top surface of the sample was measured using coherence scanning interferometry, which is particularly suited to the measurement of these nominally planar samples [7]. This enables us to observe which new defects have been introduced at each stage, and to see how defects from previous steps have affected subsequent depositions. The resulting surface topography maps for each layer are shown in Fig. 1. Measurements were taken over the full 16mm by 16mm area of the sample, but a smaller 2.2mm by 1.7mm sub-region is considered here since we are interested in small features. The total thickness of the device (excluding the glass substrate) is around 700nm and the diameter of the silica microspheres is an order of magnitude larger. As a result, the height-scales of the topography images measured after deposition of this ‘dust’ are truncated at 100nm so that the smaller scale structure is clearly visible alongside the positions (but not heights) of the microspheres.

The surface topography maps in Fig. 1 show multiple features and defects that are present in the device, examples of which are labelled A-F in Fig. 1(c). The silica microspheres (e.g. ‘A’) are clearly visible as circular features in the MoOx/Ag and active layer images but absent from the ZnO and ITO, as expected from the layer deposition sequence. The other defects, labelled ‘B–F’, were not introduced deliberately so their identities are unknown, however, by comparing the images of the different layers, we can identify at which point in the deposition process they first appear and can suggest likely causes. Defect ‘B’ is present in every layer (more clearly visible in the corresponding line profiles shown in the Supplementary information). Therefore, we conclude that this is a defect or foreign particle on the ITO layer that is present prior to the first measurement. Defects ‘C’ and ‘D’ both appear during the active layer deposition step, so are identified as dust particles or aggregates suspended within the active layer solution, or dust particles arriving before or after the deposition itself. More specifically, ‘C’ appears as a lower lying region of the active layer (a negative defect) with the surface height descending towards the centre from all sides (Supplementary information). This can arise either from incomplete wetting of the active layer solution during blade coating, or by the incorporation of a particle that subsequently detached from the surface. In contrast, defect ‘D’ shows a much sharper step in the height profile, which is consistent with a particle remaining in place. The shape and size of this feature (roughly 0.26mm long and 0.03mm wide) suggest that this is a fibrous dust particle. Defects ‘E’ and ‘F’ appear during the ZnO deposition. Defect ‘F’ is relatively large (around 0.5mm across) and so is probably an aggregate of ZnO rather than a foreign dust particle, whereas defect ‘E’ represents a linear feature of slightly increased height (~5nm) relative to the rest of the film, which we identify as a ‘ripple’ in the ZnO layer. Furthermore, we observe that these ‘ripples’ are arranged radially on the sample and so we associate them particularly with the spin coating process by which the ZnO precursor is deposited.

In order to investigate how these defects relate to the photovoltaic performance of the solar cell, we use a customised light beam induced photocurrent mapping (LBIC) instrument [6,8–11].
Fig. 2 shows photocurrent maps of the whole sample and the smaller region of interest.

The photocurrent map of the whole sample demonstrates the significant impact of processing defects and inhomogeneities on the functional performance of OPV devices, with the measured photocurrent at different positions within the active areas varying from <1µA to >5µA. A uniformly optimised performance might, therefore, be expected to yield a significant improvement in overall device performance – we calculate that this would give an overall increase in photocurrent by a factor of 2.6 under these conditions [9,10]. To make a quantitative comparison between the functional impact of defects ‘A–F’, we extract the maximum (for ‘C’, ‘E’, and ‘F’) or minimum (for ‘A’, ‘B’, and ‘D’) recorded photocurrent value associated with each defect and compare it with the average over the whole device to give a value, ΔLBIC , where:

These values are given in Table 1. Significantly, both the silica microsphere, ‘A’ and the fibrous dust particle, ‘D’ result in comparable local reductions in photocurrent (−41% and −71%, respectively) indicating that the microspheres are a good artificial substitute for dust. Defect ‘B’ also causes a similar reduction in photocurrent (−21%). However, the negative defect ‘C’ results in a small increase (7%) in local photocurrent, and both ZnO defects, ‘E’ and ‘F’ lead to increases of 6% and 84%, respectively. The local decreases in photocurrent for defects ‘A’, ‘B’, and ‘D’ readily fit the expectation that defects are detrimental to functionality, but the increased photocurrents for ‘C’, ‘E’, and ‘F’ require explanation. The probable cause of these increases in photocurrent is light scattering, where light hitting the defect is scattered into other parts of the active layer such that the enhancement arises from increased optical-coupling efficiency and delocalised excitation but not directly from the local photovoltaic performance. We notice that the peak of the photocurrent associated with defect ‘F’ is not in the same position as the peak of the surface height, which is consistent with this explanation. This scattering effect is particularly expected to arise where the defect is large and irregular, as is the case for defect ‘F’, but might also explain the smaller effects observed for ‘C’ and ‘E’. Additionally, the functionality of the device is sensitive to the thicknesses of the various layers, due to optical cavity effects [12]. As a result, small variations in layer thickness could lead to differences in the local photocurrent, which might be significant in the case of the ‘ripples’ in the ZnO layer, e.g. defect ‘E’.

The combination of surface topography data with steady state photocurrent mapping enables us to identify correlations between the nature of the defects and the device performance. However, these conclusions are subject to the caveats described above, and do not reveal the mechanisms by which the various defect structures affect the device functionality. In order to gain a mechanistic understanding of the effects of these defects on photovoltaic performance, we also consider the local charge carrier dynamics by measuring the transient response of the device to nanosecond pulsed photoexcitation.

Transient photovoltage (TPV) and transient photocurrent (TPC) measurements are an established technique for probing the charge carrier dynamics of OPV devices. Previous studies have used the TPC signal to reveal the charge extraction dynamics and have demonstrated that the TPV signal is a good measure of the charge carrier density in the device, such that the transient decay corresponds well with the recombination rate of the photogenerated charge [13,14]. These studies have considered the macroscopic case, where the laser pulse photoexcites the whole device. In contrast, we investigate the case where the excitation is focused to a small (50–70µm diameter) spot, in order to obtain a spatially resolved transient measurement. The analysis of TPV and TPC measurements in the case of macroscopic (expanded beam) excitation relies on considering the excitation as a small perturbation. In spatially resolved (focused beam) measurements, the gain in spatial resolution requires an increase in excitation laser intensity to obtain a measurable signal, and so the interpretation based on a small perturbation is no longer valid [13,15]. As a result, the quantitative interpretation of TPV and TPC mapping data requires additional investigation and will be dealt with in a separate publication, but the results presented here reveal qualitative differences, which are more readily understood.

Fig. 3 shows examples of TPV and TPC signals measured at a single spot on the device; the experimental conditions were the same in both cases except that the input impedance of the oscilloscope was high (1MΩ) for TPV and low (50Ω) for TPC. Recorded signals are averaged over 64 laser pulses. The background signal was set to zero by subtracting the average of the signal measured prior to excitation and then the transient was fitted with a generic double exponential decay function.

Fig. 3 indicates the meanings of the parameters ΔV, α.ΔV, and TV α extracted from the TPV transient and ΔI, α.ΔI, TI α, and ΔQ from the TPC transient. ΔV and ΔI are the peak heights of the fitted signals; α represents a fraction of the peak height, from which the corresponding decay times TV α and TI α are extracted; and ΔQ is the integral of the measured TPC signal, equivalent to the total charge extracted. The forms of both the TPC and TPV transients are similar but the TPC decay time is typically an order of magnitude faster than the TPV time (for α=0.1: TV 0.1~100µs and TI 0.1~6µs). This difference arises because the TPV signal is measured at approximately open circuit so the decay primarily represents the charge recombination dynamics, whereas the TPC signal is measured close to short circuit so the signal decay predominantly represents the charge extraction, which occurs on a faster timescale [13].

Fig. 4 shows the measured TPV mapping results by plotting the peak photovoltage, ΔV, and decay time, TV 0.1. Comparing the magnitude of the transient photovoltage signal (Fig. 4(a) and (b)), with the steady state photocurrent (Fig. 2), we find that the two measurements largely detect the same features, but the relative signal strengths for different features are different in the two cases. We expect a close correspondence between the figures since the magnitude of both signals depends on the charge density generated by the laser spot at each point; however, the measurement conditions are different in the two cases since there is no bias light used in the transient measurement. The absence of a bias light improves the signal-to-noise ratio of the TPV measurement because the background charge carrier density is close to zero and so a small difference in charge carrier density causes a larger variation in photovoltage. The map of TV 0.1 (Fig. 4(c)) shows no distinct features except for the peak at the top-left corner, corresponding with defect ‘F’, which has a decay time (TV 0.1) of ~160µs compared with an average of ~100µs elsewhere, indicating a reduction in the charge recombination rate. However, as we have noted, the optical scattering effect can result in a delocalised excitation of the sample such that it is difficult to distinguish whether the reduced charge recombination rate is a local property of the sample or an effect of delocalised excitation, whereby regions with lower photogenerated charge densities might be expected to display slower charge recombination. The light scattering effect is comparable with the use of a defocused laser excitation spot, and longer-lived transient signals with greater magnitudes are observed experimentally in both cases. Other features in this map show poor contrast due to the high level of noise.

The measured TPC data for the region of interest are given in Fig. 5, showing plots of the total charge extracted, ΔQ, and the photocurrent decay time, TI 0.1. The map of ΔQ (Fig. 5(a)) is similar to the corresponding map of ΔV (Fig. 4(b)), showing the same features with similar relative magnitudes. However, in contrast to the TPV regime, the TPC mapping is able to distinguish unambiguous variation in the decay times, TI 0.1, of the fitted transients for different regions. The features in Fig. 5(b) correspond closely with the pattern of defects identified in Fig. 1(c), and in general the positions of the defects correspond with an increased value of TI 0.1 up to ~6.5µs, compared with an average value of 6.0µs. Significantly, not all of the features in the map of TI 0.1 correlate perfectly with those in the map of ΔQ. Most obviously, in the case of defect ‘F’, ΔQ (as well as the parameters LBIC, ΔV, and TV 0.1) has a peak value at the position x=0.23mm, y=1.48mm, which is not represented in the TI 0.1 map. This shows that the TPC decay time reveals functional information that is not available using these other techniques. We understand this observation by identifying the strongest peak in the ΔQ, LBIC, ΔV, and TV 0.1 maps as originating from a light scattering defect, whereas the features shown in the TI 0.1 map correspond with charge extraction defects. This distinction is made more apparent by considering the correlation between the measured values of TI 0.1 and ΔQ for all the data points in the TPC map – this is plotted in Fig. 5(c). This plot shows that the majority of data points cluster around mean values of TI 0.1 ≈6.0μs and ΔQ ≈7.2×10-10 C, but the distribution shows two other distinct populations:
(i)
Light Scattering Defects. This population is characterised by high ΔQ values (>8.5×10-10 C) and average TI 0.1 values. These defects enhance the coupling of the incident light into the active layer by scattering the beam into other regions of the device. This can result in an increase in the total charge generated by the excitation, leading to an increase in the measurements of ΔQ, LBIC and ΔV. Light scattering tends to delocalise the optical excitation such that the charge extraction dynamics do not correspond with the local properties of the sample. As a result, the charge extraction dynamics measured for these points are centred around the sample average. However, we might also expect the scattered light to result in relatively low photogenerated charge densities at some points in the device, which will therefore exhibit reduced charge recombination rates and a consequent increase in the measured TV 0.1 value.
(ii)
Charge Extraction Defects. This population is characterised by long TI 0.1 times (>6.2μs) and lower than average ΔQ values. These defects are regions of the sample where charge extraction is impaired. As a result, the charge extraction rate is reduced, leading to an increased measured value of TI 0.1, and the total charge extracted, ΔQ, is correspondingly reduced due to increased competition from recombination (note that this does not require any local variation in the charge recombination rate probed by TV 0.1 under quasi-open circuit conditions). In addition to charge recombination, a contribution to the local reduction in ΔQ could also arise from reduced light harvesting if the defect causes a local reduction in active layer thickness or the optical coupling efficiency.

By considering both the TPC decay times and total charge extracted together, we are now able to distinguish additional information regarding the various defects ‘A-F’ labelled in Fig. 1. We find that the large ZnO aggregate (defect ‘F’) falls mainly within the class of light scattering defects, though some parts of it do also appear to have an impact on charge extraction. Conversely, the silica microspheres (e.g. defect ‘A’), and the dust fibre (defect ‘D’) can be classed as charge extraction defects due to the local increase in TPC decay time. This interpretation agrees with our expectation that the inclusion of insulating particles between the ZnO and active layer would hinder the efficient extraction of charge. The other defects, ‘B’, ‘C’, and ‘E’ do not show distinct properties in the transient response data, which indicates that they have a smaller impact on the device performance, despite appearing as significant in the topography map. The inset in Fig. 5(c) plots the spatial positions of the points assigned to the two distinct defect populations and demonstrates how this type of technique could be used to provide clear identification of different classes of defect.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated the correlation of surface topography measurements with photovoltaic functional mapping as a tool for probing the impact of defects and inhomogeneities on the performance of OPV devices. The development of transient photocurrent and photovoltage mapping provides a unique insight into the local charge carrier dynamics of the photovoltaic device. Taking the example of insulating dust particles introduced between the hole-extracting electrode and active layer, we find that the local reduction in steady state photocurrent generation corresponds with an increase in the transient photocurrent decay time, indicating a reduction in charge extraction efficiency. Importantly, this measurement also enables us to distinguish light scattering defects, which are a particular problem for steady state photocurrent mapping since the measured response does not represent the local properties at the site of the defect. The ability to probe the mechanisms by which different defects and inhomogeneities affect the functionality of printed solar cells is an important step towards commercialisation of this technology, where critical and non-critical defects need to be reliably identified.

The EMRP is jointly funded by the participating countries within EURAMET and the European Union. Materials were supplied by Merck Chemicals Ltd. Thanks are due to George Dibb and Gareth Hinds for valuable discussions.
